Award.AwardTitle: CRCNS: Collaborative Research: Dynamic Models of Human Auditory Perceptual Switching Informed by Large-Scale ECoG Recordings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sounds in natural environments are complex mixtures from many different sources. This project seeks to understand how humans organize mixtures of sounds into meaningful objects. Perceptions of auditory objects arise not from any particular part of the brain, but rather from coordinated activity across many brain regions; further, binding of sounds to auditory objects may switch very rapidly. Therefore, the study of how auditory objects are formed and how rapid switching occurs requires analyzing recordings of brain activity in humans across many brain areas and at very high speed. This project aims to develop new theoretical methods for integrating and analyzing complex dynamic data sets of brain recordings from large-scale electrode arrays. The modeling approach will provide insight in the understanding of human auditory perception in both normal and clinically impaired minds.

Significant advances have been made in the past three decades characterizing neural correlates of auditory perceptions localized to the auditory cortex. Nevertheless, these neural correlates are likely not restricted to the auditory cortex, or to any particular part of the brain. To understand the neural mechanisms of auditory perceptual representation and perceptual switching, the current project combines advances in both experimental design and theory. Large-scale electrocorticography (ECoG) recordings will be collected from human subjects as they self-report their perceptions during a bistable auditory task involving rapid perceptual switching. Next, spatial-temporal patterns of cortical activation during the task will be extracted from these large time-series datasets using a data-driven method novel to neuroscience known as dynamic mode decomposition (DMD). Features extracted by DMD will then be used to build data-driven, low-dimensional dynamic models that capture the temporal evolution of multiple cortical areas, encoding both the auditory stimulus and the perceptual state.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Investigators Rodica Curtu and Kirill V. Nourski from The University of Iowa (UI), together with their collaborator Bingni W. Brunton from University of Washington (UW), have completed research on neural correlates of bistable auditory perception, funded by the NSF CRCNS program.

The human brain has the remarkable ability to make sense of complex and ambiguous stimulus from the external world, parsing mixed inputs into interpretable segments. However, one's perception, a subjective experience, can sometimes deviate from objective reality. Exploiting such perceptual discrepancies has been for long a popular goal of artists and magicians; at the same time, these discrepancies offered neuroscientists a unique view of neural mechanisms of how conscious perceptions arise, as distinct from neural activity driven by the physical stimulus. But understanding how perception is created from stimulus and which brain areas are involved in the processing of sensory input, has been hindered by two critical experimental challenges: (1) limited access to brain recordings with wide spatial coverage and high resolution in space and time, in humans performing behavioral tasks, and (2) an inherent difficulty to separate the stimulus driven activity from the perception per se.

Researchers Curtu, Nourski and Brunton have overcome such obstacles by obtaining invasive brain recordings (human electrocorticography; ECoG) during an auditory task with a stimulus that supports two mutually exclusive perceptual interpretations. The lab recorded behavioral and ECoG data from neurosurgical patients as they listened to sequences of repeated triplets of tones characterized by fixed frequency difference, DF, and reported their ongoing perception. Over the course of the stimulus, the subjects reported spontaneous alternations between two percepts: a galloping-like, coherent auditory stream (1-stream) and two simultaneously heard, but distinct, streams (2-stream).

Curtu-Nourski-Brunton's work uncovered percept-related neuronal differences in auditory streaming of triplets (differences in the average evoked potential associated with 1-stream and 2-stream percepts) in core and non-core auditory cortex, surrounding auditory-related temporoparietal cortex, and frontal areas. It also confirmed and expanded findings from non-invasive studies of auditory streaming of triplets. In particular, the data recorded by their research group clarified previously reported topographic dissimilarities of triplet epoch waveforms in magnetoencephalography (MEG) and electroencephalography (EEG) measurements. Researchers Curtu, Nourski and Brunton introduced a novel approach to the analysis of multidimensional ECoG data by using projections on one-dimensional spaces, as a framework for the construction of data-driven dynamic models of perceptual bistability. They also demonstrated that activity from the auditory cortex encoded sustained perceptual states as well as transition between them, in support of the hypothesis that similar neural substrates underlie switches and maintenance of the percepts.

In a separate set of experiments, the research group recorded behavioral data from healthy human subjects as they listened to sequences of repeated triplets of tones as described above. The subjects reported spontaneous alternations between two percepts; the probability of the 2-stream percept from trial-averaging increased over seconds, from near-zero to a DF-dependent steady value, defining the buildup function. First and subsequent percept durations followed gamma-like distributions and had DF-dependent means. Curtu et al provided a theoretical framework for these experimental findings. They proposed a new evidence accumulation model for auditory streaming that took as input neurophysiological responses of primary auditory cortex. The model accounted for the dynamics of the observed psychometric buildup for various DF values; it captured DF-dependence of first and subsequent mean dominance durations; and it matched the observed percept duration distributions (gamma-like), constraints that have not been previously considered in analyses of such neural data.

 During the duration of this NSF-sponsored project, Curtu-Nourski-Brunton’s research group generated cumulatively 30 publications that appeared as conference papers (25) or were published in topics journals (5) such as The Journal of Neuroscience, NeuroImage, Frontiers in Human Neuroscience, and Frontiers  in Computational Neuroscience. They presented their scientific results at numerous national and international (Belgium, Denmark, France, Japan, Spain, Switzerland, United Kingdom) conferences and workshops. Outreach activities included contributions to the organization of the Eleventh Sonia Kovalevsky High School Mathematics Day in Iowa City, IA (a day-long event featuring talks aimed to stimulate high-school-aged female students’ interest in math and to encourage them to pursue careers in math and science) and mentoring for Girls in Science in Seattle, WA (a program run by the Burke Museum to connect middle-school girls with female scientists). Three graduate students at UI, and one post-baccalaureate and one undergraduate student at UW were partially supported by this grant.  Research results obtained in this project formed the basis of two PhD dissertations at UI; another PhD thesis is currently in preparation. The project also funded the research of one female postdoctoral fellow. She received highly interdisciplinary training, including advice for responsible professional practices, improvement of communication skills, and career counseling. Following the completion of the project, the postdoc successfully found employment in industry as a Data Scientist.
